So many mistakes in this paper. A more precise tracing and a phylogenetic analysis indicates the contents of the large ichthyosaur is an embryo only 1 meter long. The overlooked head and tail of the embryo are curled tight, as is typical of embryos, inside the amnion, in the uterus, far from the stomach. Details here: https://pterosaurheresies.wordpress.com/2020/09/19/inside-an-odd-triassic-ichthyosaur-an-odd-embryo-not-a-meal/

Icthyosaurs are as underrated as mosasaurs are overrated. The general public thinks that since icthyosaurs looked like fish they can't be more remarkable than them (which is a terribly flawed assumption itself), and mosasaurs must have been the ultimate marine predator simply because they were the dominant marine reptiles at the same time that Tyrannosaurus was alive, without realizing that similar, and frankly larger bodied, marine reptiles existed before them. Mosasaurs only became megapredators after icthyosaurs, pliosaurs, and thalattosuchids got gone extinct and mosasaurs adapted to their niches in their absence, not because they forced all other competing reptiles into extinction because they were just that badass.
